title: Giddy, a self-custody smart wallet, extends to Ethereum - crypto.news
summary: Giddy, a self-custody smart wallet, has integrated Ethereum, expanding its capabilities and accessibility across multiple networks. The wallet provider aims to integrate more platforms in the future, including Arbitrum, Base, and BNB Chain. Giddy's unique private key technology splits recovery phrases into three parts for enhanced security, and users can buy and swap tokens, as well as send assets, directly from the wallet. The CEO of Giddy described the technology as a "game changer" and stated that it simplifies user experience by breaking down private keys into multiple factors owned by the user.

title: Ethereum Staking Services Accept 22% Validators Limit Amid Criticism From ETH Community - CCN.com
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 256 tokens or less:

Ethereum staking service providers have agreed to limit their ownership to 22% of the staking market to prevent centralization.

The move comes in response to concerns about decentralization and follows a proposal by a core developer.

The 22% self-limit rule aims to maintain the network's decentralized nature by requiring at least four major companies to agree on the network's state.

Some providers have already implemented the rule, while others are working towards it.

The move has received a mixed reaction from the Ethereum community, with some arguing that it ignores the platform's tenets and others expressing concerns about centralization.

The debate highlights the ongoing commitment of the Ethereum community to preserving decentralization and ensuring the integrity of the platform.

title: StarkWare, Herodotus launch tech to verify data from any point in Ethereum's history - Cointelegraph
summary: StarkWare and Herodotus have developed a new technology that allows users to verify data from any point in Ethereum's history without needing a third party. The solution uses StarkWare's STARK proofs and on-chain accumulator, which stores block headers and enables faster verification of historical data. This technology has the potential to build "Web2 equivalent applications" and could be used for account recovery and automated insurance protocols. The two teams highlight the potential for storage proofs to replace cross-chain bridges that rely on third-party oracles to track and verify data.

title: Retail Trading Giant Robinhood To Enable In-App Swaps on the Ethereum Network for More Than 200 Crypto Assets - The Daily Hodl
summary: Robinhood, a popular retail trading platform, has announced the rollout of in-app swaps on the Ethereum network for over 200 cryptocurrencies. This feature will allow users to swap their assets without needing to hold ETH tokens, with network fees automatically deducted from their existing assets. The move aims to make decentralized finance (DeFi) more accessible to everyday people. Robinhood has also launched custody, send, and receive support for Bitcoin, Dogecoin, and Ethereum in response to user demand.

title: US Court Scraps Uniswap Lawsuit, Declares Ethereum a Commodity - Securities.io
summary:
In a recent court ruling, a lawsuit against Uniswap, a popular decentralized cryptocurrency exchange (DEX), was dismissed. The plaintiffs, a group of investors, claimed that Uniswap violated US securities laws by failing to register as an exchange or broker-dealer while offering and soliciting securities on an unregistered exchange. However, the court ruled that the true defendants in the case were the issuers of the "scam tokens" listed on Uniswap, and not the DEX itself.

The ruling is a significant victory for the DeFi (decentralized finance) industry, as it clarifies how US securities laws apply to DeFi transactions. The court also noted that Uniswap, as a decentralized platform, cannot control which tokens are listed or who can interact with it.

The case against Uniswap was built on the transfer of title theory, which argues that by drafting the smart contracts that enabled token transactions, Uniswap was effectively transferring the title of the tokens to the plaintiffs. However, the court dismissed this argument, stating that Un

title: Ethereum staking services agree to 22% limit of all validators - Cointelegraph
summary:
Sure, here is a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Ethereum staking services have agreed to limit their market share to 22% to ensure decentralization. At least five providers have committed to the self-limit, including Rocket Pool, StakeWise, Stader Labs, and Diva Staking. The proposal aims to address concerns of centralization in Ethereum staking. Lido Finance, the largest provider, voted against the self-limit proposal. The Ethereum community has mixed reactions to the proposal, with some viewing it as economically rational and others concerned about centralization.

title: Arkham identifies Grayscale's Ethereum Trust as second-largest ETH holder - CryptoSlate
summary: Arkham Intelligence identified Grayscale's Ethereum Trust as the second-largest Ethereum holder globally, with $5 billion in assets. The fund is divided across over 500 addresses, each containing $30 million or less. This discovery is significant as it highlights the scale of Grayscale's investments in Ethereum. However, there is a discrepancy between Arkham's data and Grayscale's own reports regarding other crypto funds. Grayscale obtained a legal victory, which may lead to the conversion of its GBTC fund to a spot Bitcoin ETF.

title: Polygon's new open-source L2 chain developer stack to support Ethereum ZK-powered layer 2s - Cointelegraph
summary: Polygon, a popular Ethereum layer 2 (L2) scaling solution, has released an open-source developer stack called Chain Development Kit (CDK) that utilizes zero-knowledge proof (ZK-proof) technology to enable fast and secure layer 2 protocols on Ethereum. The CDK stack provides a simple and seamless way for developers to launch ZK-powered L2s tailored to their project's requirements. Key features include automatic access to liquidity across Polygon's chains and the wider Ethereum ecosystem, customizable options for rollup or validium mode, zkEVM or other ZK-powered execution environments, and native token and gas token customization. The CDK stack is also designed to connect chains launched with it to a shared ZK bridge and plug them into an interop layer, which enables cross-chain communication and sub-minute transactions. In an exclusive interview with Cointelegraph, Polygon's co-founder and technical lead, Jordi Baylina, emphasized the importance of ZK-proof technology in scaling Ethereum and highlighted the customizability of the CDK stack for different

title: Exploring Starknet: The Rising Star of Layer 2 Solutions for Ethereum - BSC NEWS
summary: Starknet is a layer 2 solution for Ethereum that utilizes zero-knowledge proofs to enhance privacy and security. It has gained popularity within the StarkWare ecosystem and is attracting attention from the broader community. Key features include faster transaction finality, layer 1 data storage, capital efficiency, and withdrawal flexibility. However, there are limitations such as the native programming language Cairo and the need for specialized hardware for validity proofs. Starknet has a growing ecosystem with various projects, including NFTs, DeFi, and fully on-chain games. The platform has also introduced a native token, $STARK, with a lock-up period and a forthcoming airdrop.

The daily chart shows a failed retest of the $1,750 level, with a potential breakdown towards $1,400. title: Bitcoin, Ethereum Drop After SEC Delays ETF Decision - Decrypt
summary:
Sure, here's a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Bitcoin and Ethereum prices dropped after the SEC delayed its decision on ETF approval. The SEC extended the deadline by 45 days, citing the need for additional time to evaluate the applications. This move crushed market optimism, causing Bitcoin to briefly drop below $26,000. Ethereum followed with a 3.5% dip. Maker and Toncoin were the only two cryptocurrencies that saw positive gains, with Maker up 5% and Toncoin up 3%. The global macroeconomic landscape also sent mixed signals, with the US Bureau of Economic Analysis releasing data that reduced market expectations for an interest rate hike. The US Personal Consumption Expenditures price index for July was 3.3%, aligning with market expectations and raising hopes that the Fed might pause on interest rate hikes. Investors are awaiting the August US employment data for more clarity on the potential rate hike decision.

title: Ethereum (ETH) is a Commodity Says Judge in Uniswap Lawsuit - Crypto Briefing
summary:
Sure, here's a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Ethereum (ETH) is considered a commodity by a New York judge in a recent lawsuit against Uniswap, rejecting a class action suit. The judge cited the ability to lawfully exchange ETH and Bitcoin as evidence. The SEC has avoided labeling ETH as a security since Gary Gensler took office, despite believing "everything other than Bitcoin" is a security. The SEC uses the Howey Test to determine if a transaction qualifies as an investment contract, but has recently ruled that other assets, including Solana, Polygon, and Cardano, are securities. Ethereum's price dropped 2.1% in the past 24 hours.

title: Bitcoin, Ethereum Trading Volumes Headed for Worst Quarter Since 2019 - Decrypt
summary: Bitcoin and Ethereum trading volumes are expected to reach their lowest levels since 2019, with September volumes potentially hovering around $350 billion for Bitcoin and $220 billion for Ethereum. This marks a decline of 14% and 43%, respectively, from the previous quarter. The decrease in trading volumes is attributed to a lack of liquidity in the spot market and the increasing importance of derivatives in the future growth of crypto volume.

title: OnlyFans Parent Company's Ethereum Investments Revealed in Financial Report - TOKENPOST
summary: Fenix International, the parent company of OnlyFans, invested nearly $20 million in Ethereum in 2021-2022, with a $8.5 million loss by November 2022. Despite this, the company's overall revenue saw a 17% increase, from $5 billion to almost $6 billion. The platform also experienced growth in content creators (47%) and subscribers (27%). Fenix International has been exploring the digital asset space, allowing creators to use Ethereum-fueled NFTs as profile images and launching an innovative platform trading 3D celebrity cards on the Ethereum-based solution, Polygon.

To purchase the phone, buyers needed an ethOS non-fungible token (NFT), which is currently selling for around $5,000 on OpenSea. The phone will be available for regular sale in Fall 2023.

title: Ethereum is labeled ‘Commodity’ in the Uniswap Case: Insights from Legal Expert - Coinpedia Fintech News
summary: In a recent court case involving Uniswap users, Judge Katherine Polk Failla ruled that Ethereum (ETH) and Bitcoin (BTC) are considered "crypto commodities," not securities. This decision has implications for how tokens are classified in the US legal system. Expert Elena believes that this ruling could impact how courts view liquid staking setups and taxes for smart contracts. Bill Hughes, regulatory chief at Ethereum booster ConsenSys, also tweeted about the ruling, stating that the judge's decision was "pretty definitive."

title: Bitwise withdraws Bitcoin and Ether Market Cap ETF application - Cointelegraph
summary: Bitwise, an asset management firm, has withdrawn its application for a Bitcoin and Ether Market Cap Weight Strategy exchange-traded fund (ETF) that was initially filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on August 3. The withdrawal comes as a surprise, as market sentiment had turned bullish following Grayscale's SEC victory. Bitwise's chief investment officer, Matt Hougan, had advocated for SEC approval of all ETFs in a recent interview. The ETF was intended to invest in either Bitcoin (BTC) futures contracts or Ether (ETH) futures contracts, based on market capitalization. Bitwise had also collaborated with ProShares to launch another ETF around the same time. In a statement, Bitwise said that the Trust no longer intends to seek effectiveness of the Fund and no securities of the Fund were sold, or will be sold, pursuant to the above-mentioned Post-Effective Amendment to the Trust’s Registration Statement. The SEC has delayed its decision on Bitcoin ETF applications from several fir

title: Cross-Chain Versus Multi-Chain - LCX
summary:
Sure, here's a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Cross-chain and multi-chain are two concepts in blockchain technology that have different focuses and use cases. Cross-chain enables the transfer of assets between different blockchain networks, while multi-chain enables the use of multiple blockchains within a single ecosystem. Cross-chain technology is ideal for use cases that require high scalability, low latency, and cost-effectiveness, while multi-chain technology is well-suited for use cases that require enhanced security options for protecting sensitive data or information. Both technologies are helping to shape the future of blockchain technology, enabling new use cases and applications that were previously impossible.

title: Bitcoin and Ethereum classified as commodities: the final ruling of a New York court - The Cryptonomist
summary: Bitcoin and Ethereum have been classified as commodities by a New York court, according to a ruling that may impact the SEC's ongoing legal battles with crypto exchanges. The ruling was made in a lawsuit filed against Uniswap and its founder, Hayden Adams, over allegations of scam tokens on the platform. The court dismissed the case, citing the decentralized nature of the protocol and the lack of relevant regulation to hold issuers of scam tokens accountable. The ruling could have implications for the SEC's efforts to regulate the crypto industry and may provide a legal precedent for other cases involving decentralized platforms.

title: Ethereum Imposes 22% Self-Limit Rule To Ensure Decentralization - Blockzeit
summary:
Sure, here is a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Ethereum has implemented a 22% self-limit rule for staking services to ensure decentralization. At least five providers have adopted the rule, which restricts their ownership of the staking market to 22% or less. This is to prevent any single entity from gaining too much control over the network and to maintain decentralization. Lido Finance, the largest staking provider, voted against the rule, but the majority of stakers support it. The rule is seen as a balance between market growth and network decentralization.
